sentence.text: Twenty-one-years-old primigravida (consanguineously married) (Figure 1) of 20 weeks gestational age (GA) was referred with fetal USG showing short long bones which were suggestive of a lethal skeletal dysplasia.
First trimester scans had shown increased nuchal translucency (NT) (3.1 mm) and increased nuchal fold thickness (5.3 mm) at 14 weeks GA.
NIPT for common aneuploidies reported low risk.

At 20 weeks of GA, USG showed bilateral short femur length (FL) measuring 1.55 cm, tibia 1.28 cm, humerus 1.39 cm, radius 1.56 cm, and ulna 1.59 cm (greater than 4SD below the mean), abdominal circumference (AC) 12.2 cm, head circumference (HC) 17.2 cm, FL/AC ratio 0.127 (ratio of <0.16 is suggestive of lethal skeletal dysplasia), bilateral club foot, and mild polyhydramnios.
Additional details about range and standard deviations of long bones are enclosed in the supplement 1.1.
Long bones appeared broad and showed minimal bowing in lower limbs.
Specific morphological details of hands could not be appreciated.
Thoracic circumference at the level of cardiac chamber was 12.5 cm.
Abdominal visceral evaluation appeared unremarkable.
Ratio of thoracic-abdominal (TC/AC) circumference was 0.93.
Elbow joint appeared abnormal although specific details could not be ascertained (Figure S1a–e, Supporting Information).
Fetal MRI examination confirmed short limbed fetus.
Short and slightly bowed long bones of lower limbs were observed along with short long bones of upper limbs.
Both elbow joints appeared deformed with poor outline of distal humerus.
Hitch-hiker deformity of the thumb noted was a retrospective finding (Figure 1a–f).
CNS, spine, and abdominal viscera were normal.
Estimated total lung volume was 24.8 ML (O/E ratio of total lung volume is 1.6, when we used Mayer criteria at 20 weeks) (Supplement 1.2) (Meyers et al., 2018).
The ratio did not suggest possible lung hypoplasia and hence did not predict lethality by this criterion.
There was moderate polyhydramnios.
Parents decided to terminate the pregnancy.
During postnatal fetal examination the 20 weeks GA fetus weighed 250 g, HC 17.5 cm, AC 1.5 cm, interpupillary distance of 2.5 cm, and inner canthal distance 1.5 cm.

Facial features included high forehead, hypertelorism, crease below lower eyelids, depressed broad nasal bridge, anteverted nares, broad nasal base, long thin philtrum, low set ears, small mouth and microretrognathia (Figure 2A).

Other external physical features were short neck, bilateral hitchhiker thumb, bilateral single transverse crease, bilateral club foot (right side more severe than the left side), and left fifth toe is curved and dorsiflexed.
Right foot showing increased gap between T1/T2 and T4/T5.
Right T5 was somewhat laterally deviated.
Overall, all four short limbs along with bowing of lower limbs (Figure 2B,C).
Internal organ examination showed mucosal cleft palate (Figure 2D) and hypoplastic lungs.
Postmortem radiographic evaluation of the fetus confirmed short long bones (<−4SD) with symmetrical involvement of proximal, middle and distal bones.
Bones showed minimal bowing.
Both distal humeri were deformed with a broad proximal end and showed minimal sclerosis.
Clavicles appeared thick and showed abrupt angle at the junction of middle and outer third.
Both scapulae are stout and rounded.
There was bilateral subluxation of elbow joints.
Hands revealed bilateral hitch-hiker thumb deformity.
Phalanges were broad and short.
Right great toe showed excessive outward angulation.
No fractures were noted.
Skull bones were unremarkable.
However, there was global decrease in vertebral height and vertebral bodies were very small in lumbar region and absent in upper cervical region.
A hemivertebra was present at D5.
Thoracic cage was normal.
Pelvic bones were represented by somewhat horizontally oriented ileum.
Iliac bones are short, appear horizontally oriented, and demonstrate notched, sclerotic medial margins (Figure 2a–d).
Standard chromosome analyses at resolution 450–500 was normal 46,XY.
